channel.description: The latest content from IBM developerWorks

item.title: Building Web Services Security with WSDK V5.1
item.description: Security is a key component of any enterprise-grade Web service. This tutorial begins with a primer on basic security concepts (authentication, authorization, encryption, etc.), followed by a broad look at the evolving Web services security sector (WS-Security). Next, we explore three security technologies: Secure HTTP with SSL, XML Encryption, and XML Digital Signatures. Finally, we will walk through the details involved in securing a SOAP exchange, and compare and contrast various security options .

item.title: Charming Python: Review of Python IDEs
item.description: How do the latest and greatest open-source Python IDEs measure up? At long last, Python wizard David Mertz takes another look at Python development environments; we meet four of them: jEdit, Leo, IDLEfork and PythonIDE -- in the latest installment of Charming Python.

item.title: Create a portable Web service in multiple J2EE environments
item.description: Ivy Ho explains how to create Web services with WebSphere Studio Application Developer that can be deployed to multiple J2EE-compliant runtimes and application servers.

item.title: Cultured Perl: Fun with MP3 and Perl, Part 1
item.description: Perl programmer Ted Zlatanov takes a look at manipulating and tagging metadata-friendly file formats, using MP3 music files as his example. Learn Perl coding techniques, and use his autotag.pl application to organize and automate tagging for your own music files.

item.title: Eye on performance: Micro performance benchmarking
item.description: Java performance enthusiasts Jack Shirazi and Kirk Pepperdine, Director and CTO of JavaPerformanceTuning.com, follow performance discussions all over the Internet to see what's troubling developers. While surfing the Usenet newsgroup comp.lang.java, they came across some interesting low-level performance tuning questions. In this installment of "Eye on performance," they dive into some bytecode analysis to try and answer some of these questions.

item.title: Single sign-on with Tivoli Access Manager
item.description: Single sign-on allows a user to enter an ID and password once, and thereafter be able to step between various applications without being asked to re-authenticate. This tutorial shows you how to implement a single sign-on (SSO) solution using Tivoli Access Manager (TAM) WebSEAL 4.1 and the Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) 1.0 open specification.

item.title: Working XML: Map files into SOAP requests, Part 1
item.description: Many applications are being upgraded to accomodate e-commerce transactions. In the first of two articles on the subject, Benoit Marchal shows one simple approach to doing this: Create XML transactions from the export files that most business applications already produce. He discusses his experience deploying such a solution to small enterprises.
